title: 8 things announced levelling up
story: things announced in Levelling Up Plan - and our verdict on what they meanMinisters said their levelling up plans will address schools, crime, transport as well as broadband. Here, we take a look at some of the governments promises - and what they really meanMichael Gove in Westminster today Image: Tayfun Salci ZUMA Press Wire REX ShutterstockByJason BeattieHead of politicsRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsThe governmentaposs levelling up plans have been slammed as devoid of new ideas. Ministers said the missions include “improving wellbeing in every area” of the UK, a devolution deal for every part of England that wants one, and bringing public transport connectivity across the country “signicantly closer to the standards of London”.Levelling-Up Secretary Michael Gove also raised the prospect of the House of Lords moving out of London. “I think it’d be a really good thingthe House of Lords were to meet for at least part of the time in Glasgow or in York,” he told Times Radio. But Labour said all of the pledges so far have been recycled pots of money and not what we were promised.Here, we look at some of the things announced by the government, and give our verdict on what they really mean.  Schools They say: “By , the number of primary schoolchildren achieving the expected standard in reading, writing and maths will have increased.”Our verdict: The government has set a new goal of ensuring that % of schoolchildren will have reached the national standard, but in , the figure was %.Ministers have identied  communities for intensive additional support and they are largely outside of London. Quite how “intensive” this support will be delivered is also not clear.  Housing What they are promising: Improve the quality of rented homes and bring in the National Landlord Register to aid tenants. The green belt will be protected and first-time buyers will increase.Verdict: Alicia Kennedy of the Generation Rent campaign group welcomed the National Landlord Register and pledge to end no-fault evictions.But there is no extra money to build more affordable housing. No is stoking the property market by helping people get a foot on the ladder rather than investing in social housing. Mayors What they say: “By , every part of England that wants one will have a devolution deal with powers at or approaching the highest level of devolution and a simplied, long-term funding settlement.”Our verdict: Critics have hit out at the Tories’ piecemeal approach to devolving power so far, with cities having more controls than neighbouring areas, as well as the benefit of mayors such as Andy Burnham acting as national champions. The fear now is that doing deals with each area in turn could achieve the opposite of an “end to the postcode lottery”. Health and wellbeing What they say: By , the gap in Healthy Le Expectancy between local areas where it is highest and lowest will have narrowed, and by  HLE will rise by five years.Our verdict: The latest ONS data showed that the UK overall had seen the first fall in le expectancy in  years. Researchers recently found a -year gap between the le expectancy of a man living in Kensington and Cha and Blackpool. The Health Foundation says the Government “faces a massive challenge”, with funds needed to tackle smoking, obesity and NHS improvement.Crime What they are promising: By  homicide, serious violence and neighbourhood crime will have fallen, focused on the worst-affected areas.There will be , more police officers on our streets by  and a £million Safer Streets Fund to improve the environment and cut offending in high-crime areas. Verdict: There is a question mark over whether these targets can be hit. Under the Tories police officers fell from , to ,.Despite a vow to recruit , more, there are now ,. In the year to March  there was a % rise in homicides and % rise in kne crime. Latest figures show fewer than one in  crimes are solved. Transport What they say: “By , local public transport connectivity across the country will be signicantly closer to the standards of London, with improved services, simpler fares and integrated ticketing.”Our verdict: Towns and cities outside of the capital require dferent transport solutions to the economic powerhouse that is the UK’s capital, with buses and creaking rail lines badly in need of investment.The Government says the plan will take in £.billion for city regions UK-wide and £bn for the integrated rail plan. But already, promises of £bn for bus services appear to be roughly half of the cash promised, with ministers to focus on “bus improvements in areas where this can make the most impact”. The £bn integrated rail plan, meanwhile, has been watered down with the key £bn plan for Leeds to Manchester to be delivered through upgrades on the existing transpennine track, rather than a new line through Bradford.  Sports and culture What they are promising: A £bn Culture Recovery Fund for museums, theatres, cinemas and heritage groups. More Arts Council cash to go outside London. Extra support for grassroots sports.Verdict: All of these measures have been previously announced. The Culture Recovery Fund was part of the pandemic package to help venues during lockdown.While more money from the Arts Council will go to regions, its budget has not been increased. The £m for new football pitches was unveiled last June. Broadband What they are promising: By , the UK will have nationwide gigabit-capable broadband and G coverage, with G coverage for most of the population.Verdict: Not only a re-announcement – it’s actually a delay. title: blanket ban mobile phones english
story: Blanket ban on mobile phones in English schools ditched in Government U-turnFormer Education Secretary Gavin Williamson pushed for a ban on mobiles last year - but the move has been abandonedMobile phones could be banned from schools across England by early Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Feb |comments Plans for a ban on the use of mobile phones during the school day have been dropped, the Government has admitted.Updated guidance on improving discipline will leave it for heads to decide whether phones can be used in classrooms. Former Education Secretary Gavin Williamson pushed for a ban on mobiles last year, which he said were “not just distracting but they can have a damaging effect on a pupil’s mental health and wellbeing”. The move drew criticism from teaching unions, who branded it a distraction from wider issues facing schools after the pandemic.His successor Nadhim Zahawi has now stepped back from a blanket ban with revised guidance for heads, which will be consulted on from today. Children who are not in school will also be listed on a new register in an attempt to stop pupils falling through the cracks. Local authorities will be told to log where each child is being educated after a rise in children being home-schooled during the pandemic.Mr Zahawi said:While the majority of children already learn in a calm and well-maintained classroom, and some learn at home with dedicated parents, there are areas across the country where high standards are not being met.As Education Secretary, it is my priority to make sure every child gets the start in le they deserve, which is why Iaposm announcing clearer guidance to help every school boost behaviour and new legislation to create the first local authority register for children not in school. Paul Whiteman, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers , welcomed the introduction of a register for children not in school - but branded new guidance on behaviour unhelpful.  He said: We need to remember that in the vast majority of schools there are no major issues when it comes to behaviour, and that schools already have strong systems in place for supporting good behaviour. The Governmentaposs current obsession with being seen to apostalk toughapos on behaviour is frankly unhelpful. Instead, what the Government should be focusing on is making sure that vital support services are available to support schools and pupils when they need it. It is important to find outthere is an underlying cause for an inidual childaposs behaviour, whether it be mental wellbeing, undiagnosed SEND, or problems at home. Geoff Barton, General Secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said: We are relieved to see that the Education Secretary clearly doesn’t share his predecessor’s obsession with the use of mobile phones in classrooms. He appears to have accepted what we told Gavin Williamson at the time, namely that schools and colleges already have rigorous policies in place on mobile phone use and should be left to get on with the job at hand. story: Northern Ireland minister orders halt to border checks in fresh Brexit chaosDUP minister Edwin Poots ordered officials to stop checks at Northern Irelands ports - which are required under Boris Johnsons Brexit deal Image: PAByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Feb |comments Border checks are set to be suspended in Northern Irelandaposs ports from midnight in a fresh Brexit row.DUP minister Edwin Poots ordered officials to stop checks on food and farming goods coming into Northern Ireland, which are required under Boris Johnsonaposs Brexit deal. The UK and the EU agreed that goods from Great Britain must be checked at Northern Irelandaposs ports to ensure they comply with EU laws. But Mr Poots argued the checks are unlawful after seeking legal advice. Speaking at Stormont, Mr Poots said: I have now issued a formal instruction to my permanent secretary to halt all checks that were not in place on December   from midnight tonight.  I will prepare a paper for Executive consideration in the near future to seek agreement on a way forward. But it is unclear whether the senior civil servant in his department will comply with the order. Northern Irelandaposs Deputy First Minister Michelle OaposNeill branded the decision a stunt. She said: This stunt is an attempt by the DUP to unlawfully interfere with domestic, and international law. DUP fixated on their own priorities, which are clearly at odds with where the wider community is at. The move comes amid ongoing tensions between the EU and the UK over a key part of the Brexit deal, known as the Northern Ireland protocol. The protocol was designed to prevent ato violence on the island of Ireland by avoiding a land border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Island. Instead, a trade border was effectively created in the Irish Sea. Mr Johnson has spent most of the past two years trying to tear apart the Brexit deal he negotiated to reduce these checks, which have caused red tape and delays for businesses and consumers in Northern Ireland.Foreign Secretary Liz Truss has taken over the negotiations following the resignation of Brexit Minister Lord Frost, who repeatedly threatened to unilaterally tear up the deal.The DUP are opposed to the NI protocol, as they fear it means Northern Ireland is treated dferently to the rest of the UK. Sunak sat in a packed House of Commons on Monday despite a close family member testing positive for Covid, the Mirror can reveal.The Chancellor nestled between Boris Johnson and Home Secretary Priti title: the tory party is over
story: What the Tories think of Boris Johnson is irrelevant. The PM will soon be out on his earThe Conservative Party is like an abused we with no other home to go to, and in two minds about whether this is survivable, says Fleet Street Fox. It isnt Image: Getty ImagesopinionByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsWell. The Prime Minister is under direct criminal investigation. The evidence of his alleged crimes are being kept hidden from him for fear of interference.And with war brewing on Europeaposs eastern flank, the PM told the enemy he didnapost have time to ring, because he had too much arse-covering to do.The Conservative Party is like an abused we with no other home to go to, and in two minds, not about whether this is acceptable, but whether itaposs survivable. And like every victim, it has yet to realisethataposs the question, then itaposs time to go.  Yesterday, a report he resisted ordering was not published. Instead, there was an aposupdateapos on the alleged criminality of his office, his staff, and his personal residence, and the PM greeted it in the same way he has every Mirror front page, ITV broadcast, and BBC breaking news update since late November: a burst of surprise and contrition with a half-le of . seconds, decaying into toxic belligerence that will linger in the bone for a thousand years. Events for which there was not enough evidence to merit an investigation by the politan Police had, in the space of a month, uncovered  witnesses,  photographs, and  pieces of paper.Despite the insufficient evidence,  out of  parties, on  dates, have met the evidential threshold for an investigation, on the grounds that those involved knew they were against the rules, there was no reasonable justication for them, and not looking into it would end Cressida Dickaposs career quicker than sending the riot squad into a candlelit vigil.One of them is an alleged gathering in the Downing Street flat on November , , which Mrs Johnsonaposs personal spokeswoman has repeatedly insisted is total nonsense, but about which there seems to be enough evidence to merit weeks of attention by an entire squad of coppers.  While the -page report has been subbed down to just , it contains all the facts needed to decide the PMaposs future. Extensive, substantive, factual information is now available, wrote Sue Gray. There were failures of leadership and judgement. There was excessive consumption of alcohol. There was no way for those working in government to stop it breaking the law. There was a serious failure to observe, not just the standards expected of those working at the heart of government, but also of the standards expected of the entire British population at the time.The killer line is in paragraph . The excuse of long hours worked in the pandemic, in a building that could not be entirely Covid-secure, was destroyed. Those challenges... also applied to key and frontline workers across the country who were working under equally,not more, demanding conditions, often at risk to their own health... criminal sanctions were applied to many... the hardship under which citizens across the country worked, lived and sadly even died while observing the Governmentaposs regulations and guidance are known only too well. Every citizen has been impacted by the pandemic. One of them is Leshie Chandrapala. Her dad drove a bus. He died of Covid, and Leshie was not allowed to be with him as he lay in a coma in ICU. She believes he died because he didnapost get PPE at work, but the government hasnapost even written a letter of condolence to her family. A fortnight after he died, and while she grieved, they threw the BYO booze Downing Street garden party. The PMaposs response to the report was to say sorry for the way itaposs been handled, not sorry for doing it. And he has a solution. I know what the issue is, he declared. I get it, and I will fix it! He says he is taking personal charge, and setting up the Office of the Prime Minister. So who was in charge of his office for the past three years  Where is the drunken boozehound who careered around Downing Street Friday night drinkathons, encouraging staffers to let off steam with a long chug on the vodka bottle  Who allowed the culture of recklessness and lawlessness, at the heart of a government that was criminalising the same sins in others  Which leader has led his party to a disgrace worse than Windrush or Grenfell or Orgreave Bring me his head! bellows Boris from the Despatch Box. I will slay this beast, the same way that I would have slain Jimmy Savile,only I didnapost think that investigating historical sex abuse was money spaffed up the wall!Other things he has taken personal control of include Brexit, social care, test and trace, the energy crisis, the ministerial code of conduct, the saving of Owen Paterson, and funding for his gold wallpaper. The fact he took personal control of the vaccines may have something to do with the fact that  million people donapost want them. How many times has he taken charge, only for things to spin out of control  How many times has he shaken up the civil service, only to be rattled himself  Read more The nation is now watching the Conservative Party the same way as the rest of the street watches a victim get out of the police car, andto their abuser. They drag with them a whole country into this deranged, gnarled, unhappy misgovernment, back to the man who wonapost promise to publish the full truth in the House of Commons, where he might be held in contempthe failed to, but will promise it in the bar, to the MPs he has lied to for years, and who have been brainwashed into thinking such a promise is a concession rather than a repetition.Meanwhile the PM only appears in public when the public can be kept away from him. Abba tribute bands are raising their prices for satin satire. Andyou want a three-word slogan to describe where we are, it is simply: another fine mess. The PM or his we may get a fixed penalty notice pictures may or may not emerge. He may be out on his ear, or he may convince enough MPs to give him one more go. Itaposs irrelevant, because the fallout of this radioactive scandal will last to the ballot box and beyond it reaches into homes and hearts, to the guts and spines of millions to whom the words aposToryapos and aposPartyapos are now as repugnant as the fact that people like Leshie had their pain doubled and then dismissed by a man whose charm has long since been spent. The Tories got drunk on power, picked a man who can be fooled by a cake, and then dithered about whether to let him keep hurting the rest of us. They cannot see what the rest of us can: their party is over. Early le of a monster Ray, born in , was primarily raised by his grandparents who were believed to have run a strict, religious household. As the siblings grew up in a tiny rural town, Peggy became a popular, outgoing girl - while Ray remained shy and something of a loner. Family and fatherhood Over the years Ray married several times and fathered lots of children, but he abandoned his families and only really bonded with a daughter he had - Glenda Jean Ray. Cynthiaaposs escape After kidnapping an unknown number of victims, Ray was finally caught in  when Cynthia Vigil escaped the Toy Box. Completely naked save for chains and a dog collar and covered in Cindyaposs blood, Cynthia fled and tried to flag down a passing car, before finding a house she considered safe and running inside. After the first trial had to be repeated, Ray was convicted of  counts of torture and sexual assault. The victim in the second trial sadly died before she could see justice, meaning no verdict was ever made. Eventually in , Ray was sentenced to  years in prison for ious offences in the abduction and torture of his victims. He was soon dubbed the Toy Box Killer as cops believed he was responsible for up to  murders - but no bodies relating to his crimes were ever recovered. Jessy Ray was given a sentence of nine years while Cindy Hendy was given  years in prison. On  May , Ray was taken to a facility in New Mexico to be questioned by state police. Shortly before the interrogation took place, he had a heart attack and died. Since managing to escape from the Toy Box, Cynthia Vigil has gone on to have a family, but she has shared her story in the hope other victims of evil Ray will come forward. Recalling her ordeal to reporters in , she said: This was a very sick man. The only thing that gives me any comfort is that he’s gone. If I didn’t get away, I wouldn’t have my three wonderful boys. I wouldn’t be here. title: catcalling unacceptable needs taken seriously
story: Catcalling is unacceptable - it needs to be taken seriously once and for allBradford Police have launched an undercover operation to combat catcalling – targeting people who are shouting things from their vehicles at women girls. This will not be tolerated.Bradford Police have launched an undercover operation to combat catcallingImage: Getty Images AlloyopinionByPolly Hudson:,  Feb |commentsIt probably seems like a small thing, at best. At worst, a waste of time and resources. It’s not though. It’s important. A tiny triumph. A baby step in the right direction. Bradford Police have launched an undercover operation to combat catcalling – “targeting people who are shouting things from their vehicles at women girls. This will not be tolerated.” Last week they stopped a van after the occupant yelled at some women who turned out to be plain-clothed police officers. Oh to have seen his face. He was reported for a breach of the Public Spaces Protection Order and is likely to be issued with a £ fine or taken to court, which is another way of saying that he was left in no doubt that THIS IS NOT OK. That’s apparently what men need to be told, reminded of, in no uncertain terms, so they’re one hundred per cent clear. No, it’s not just a bit of harmless fun that we need to lighten up about. It’s horrendous. Scary. Humiliating.  Maybe this concept is confusing because we’re living in an age of sharing, honesty, and talking about everything. Mostly that’s great, but somewhere within this, a simple truth has got lost. Sometimes, it’s good NOT to talk. Sometimes, you need to shut the hell up. Perhaps we need a massive advertising campaign, public service announcement telly commercials and posters everywhere to clearly inform everyone once and for all: Stop telling women what you think of their bodies. Especially when they haven’t asked, which is pretty much always. There are no Thought Police – anyone is free to think whatever they like. The opinions inside someone’s head can’t hurt anyone . The problem comes when they’re broadcast out loud to the woman you’re thinking them about, be it on the street, online, or on a radio show, like that fool who talked about Strictly’s Tilly Ramsay. What you think of the woman’s body is irrelevant, by the way. Evenyou believe it’s a compliment, still keep it to yourself. Of course there are exceptions to the rule, but most women do not feel flattered and delighted when a stranger gives them positive feedback about a body part. We feel embarrassed, and frightened. And we’re taught to ignore this behaviour – apart from in Bradford, it’s up to us to deal with it ourselves – to put our heads down, walk quicker, in case the situation escalates.We’re luckywe are only verbally harassed. Even online, where the threat of physical violence is removed, these kind of comments are dangerous, and unacceptable. They perpetuate the belief that women’s appearances are fair game for discussion and debate. That our bodies are anyone’s business but our own. They also ensure that the practice of speaking about women in this way seeps down to future generations, continuing the cycle. It has to stop. As the fight to make our streets safer for women goes on, catcalling being taken seriously in one city in the UK is just a drop in the ocean. But at least it’s a start. Maybe those TV ads aren’t a bad idea – and it’s obvious what music they should be set to. Ronan Keating, You Say It Best, When You Say Nothing At All. title: cruel neglectful pandemic puppy farmer
story: Cruel, neglectful pandemic puppy farmer jailed after breaking lelong dog banJeremy Awdry was sentenced to  weeks imprisonment after he admitted breaches of the dog ban, just months after it was imposedAwdry kept the puppies in squalid conditions at his home Image: Gloucestershire News ServiceByMirror:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb  A -year-old puppy farmer branded “cruel” and “neglectful” when he was convicted in court last year and disqualied from keeping dogs for le has been jailed for flouting the ban.Jeremy Awdry, of Bream, Gloucestershire - a sheep owner with commoners rights in the Forest of Dean - was sentenced yesterday to  weeks imprisonment after he admitted breaches of the dog ban, just months after it was imposed. Prosecutor Sara Anthony told Cheltenham Magistrates Court that a year ago Awdry was disqualied for le from owning, keeping, transporting or being in any way involved with dogs. The ban was imposed in February  at Gloucester Crown Court after Awdry and two other defendants were convicted for selling puppies without a licence, and failing to meet the needs of the animals. The puppies were kept in squalid conditions at Awdryaposs home and were poorly looked after. Awdry and his two accomplices were estimated to have made £, from puppy farming over four years. Yesterday, Ms Anthony told the court that the Forest of Dean District Council was tipped off that Awdry was still using dogs for work and had been seen transporting his dogs about, shortly after his dog ban was imposed. On April ,  at .am two members of the councilaposs street warden team were in the Bream area and were travelling along Oakwood Road when they spotted Awdry in a white Nissan vehicle beside a five bar gate,” Ms Anthony said. “They both had a clear view of a black and white Collie sitting on the front passenger seat. They watched Awdry turn the vehicle around and drive to the other side of the field and park alongside an outbuilding. They both saw Awdry unload two Collie dogs from the vehicle and usher them towards the outbuilding. Awdry was then observed ing to his vehicle without the dogs. Awdry drove down Highfield Close and disappeared from the area. The street wardens checked the outbuilding and observed that the two dogs were inside. While the wardens were making notes of what they had just witnessed Awdry ed in his van accompanied by his we. He parked beside the outbuilding and opened the door while Mrs Awdry encouraged the dogs into the vehicle from the passenger side. Awdry ed to the vehicle and drove off. On the second occasion the district council was contacted by PC Katherine McDay who was driving in a marked vehicle from Coleford to Bream on May  last year at around pm when she noticed Awdryaposs Nissan van on the B near the area of Bream Cross. She noticed a large amount of sheep coming from a field opposite. Pc McDay travelled past the Nissan and turned around. While she travelled back towards the van she noticed that Awdry was driving and his we was in the passenger seat with a black Collie dog on her lap. As Pc McDay passed she noticed that the dog was released out of the passenger door and it began herding sheep along the road. A short while later she noticed Awdry drive away from the area and saw that the sheep were no longer visible. The dog had its head out of the passenger window. Clive Rees, defending, said: I feel that Awdry did not fully understand the rules surrounding the disqualication order. He was under the impression thathe had somebody with him who was responsible for the dogs he would be complying with the terms of the order. Awdry had already transferred ownership of the dogs to his we. He has kept dogs all his le and, being a commoner, he has the right to roam sheep on the common. He frequently gets calls from police to remove them from the road, eventhey are not his own sheep. When the order was initially issued Awdry would get his we to drive his van with the dogs. However over the past few months Mrs Awdryaposs health has deteriorated and she has recently lost much of her eyesight and most of her hearing. Mr Awdry has become her carer. Awdry started the order with good intentions. His son has now taken over the responsibility for the dogs. Whoever saw the dogs, there was no mention of them being concerned about the animalsapos welfare. In the future Awdry will have to come to terms about not looking after sheep in future. He realises now that he is in a serious position. He should have known the position when he was sentenced at Gloucester Crown Court. Awdry pleaded guilty to breaching a disqualication order imposed after conviction on two occasions. On or around April ,  at Lydney, having been previously disqualied from keeping dogs he transported two black and white collie dogs inside a white Nissan white van, and on May ,  he transported a black and white collie dog inside the same van whilst directing  sheep to exit a field and move along the B Rd heading towards Bream. Presiding Justice Major Paul Adey sentenced Awdry to six weeks imprisonment for the two offences of transporting dogs and activated the  week suspended sentence consecutively. We note that the dogs are no longer in your and Mrs Awdryaposs ownership, a move which should have been undertaken  months ago, said the magistrate. “We also acknowledge that the dogs have not been mistreated whilst they have been in your care. The justices ordered that outstanding court costs of £, and the £, costs of yesterdayaposs case must be paid by Awdry by th April this year. After yesterdayaposs hearing Forest of Dean District Councilaposs Animal Welfare Member Champion, Councillor Nicky Packer said Our Street Warden team do a fantastic job year round of ensuring that animals in our district are looked after properly, and that those who mistreat or cause harm to their animals are held accountable.” This verdict should stand as testament to this. A ban on keeping dogs means exactly that. If, as in this case, it isnapost followed, our Street Warden and Counter Fraud and Enforcement team will enforce it. A council spokesperson added The prosecution was undertaken by Forest of Dean District Councilaposs Legal Services team working with the Councilaposs Street Wardens Team and Counter Fraud and Enforcement Unit . story: Im a professional cuddler - I make £, a month hugging strangers in my bedKristiina Link, , from east London is a certied ‘cuddle therapist,’ offering hugs to those feeling lonely and isolated, with her sessions lasting up to three hours at a timeThe -year-old holds sessions up to three hours long Image: MERCURY PRESSByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsCuddling strangers is a real job - and it will net you thousands of pounds.One woman has revealed how she makes thousands by hugging and spooning strangers - rather than your standard desk job.Kristiina Link, , from Stratford, East London, has turned a pastime into a job - and even earns up to £ per snuggling session. Her services include handholding, hair stroking and embracing her clients for up to three hours at a time.The therapist says there are many emotional benefits to the practice - and her boyfriend understands the unique demands of her job.After a breakup, heartbroken Kristiina decided to take a snuggle training course to combat her loneliness.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter hereShe said: “In , I was missing the cuddling and affectionate side of a relationship after becoming single.“I thought that there should be a service where people help each other and cuddle – Itaposs a bit like Uber for cuddles.“Hugs release the love hormone, oxytocin which is known to help with loneliness, anxiety and depression.“For this to be released, studies show that you need the hug to last at least  seconds but people normally hug for a few seconds, so they never experience the full effect.In my work, I see a lot of people who are feeling isolated because of the pandemic as well as those who are grieving and in need of physical comfort.After a y introductory process, Kristiina begins her sessions by playing meditative music and holding her clientsapos hands before cuddling up in a double bed.She said: I start by playing calming music, handholding and I encourage deep breathing so they feel present in the moment.We cuddle in multiple positions such as standing up and spooning but I change the position every  minutes otherwise arms get sore and people need to stretch.Some people are nervous at first or donapost like their hair and arms being stroked so boundaries are always discussed before we begin - itaposs important that people feel like theyaposre in a safe space and have been paired with the right person.Iaposm not a talking therapist, weaposre not trained to give advice however most people I see tend to receiving counselling or talking therapy as well as seeing me.Although it is becoming a recognised wellness trend, Kristiina says people often have a misconception about her occupation.She said: “It’s still a fairly new concept so some people get confused about what cuddle therapy actually is - It was the same for professional massages fty years ago.Mainly men visit because women tend to be touchier with their girlfriend and in general men donapost have many male friends.“I get a lot of men who work in managerial positions who want to unwind after talking and being in charge all day.Kristina sees clients who are over , however her main clients are aged between  and  years old.She said: “I see a few younger men, who are still quite shy – they might have low confidence and want to explore how to connect with a female through cuddling and touch.“I usually see single clients but there are some who are in a relationship whose partner doesn’t like cuddling or they don’t have touch love language.It is sad to hear but cuddling can teach them ways to connect with their partner and they can take these techniques back to their relationship.As well as getting her own dose of the aposloveapos hormone, Kristiina receives up to £ for her affectionate services.She said: “A one-hour session costs £ however I offer appointments for up to three hours and I apply a £ discount with those.You release the cuddling chemicals over four hours but people start to get headaches and even drowsy at the end.Three hours is the optimalfor a cuddle as more than this can lead to drowsiness, headaches and even dehydration. Too much of anything isnapost good for you and that also goes for cuddling.Although she makes a fortune from those who are desperate to be touched, Kristinaaposs main passion is to help with peopleaposs emotional needs.I donapost set my prices as high as other cuddle therapists and I apply a lot of discounts so that everyone can experience the healing power of cuddle therapy.She adds: My clients understand that cuddling is a form of plutonic touch therapy however, I’ve had regular clients who come every week and I sometimes I see that as a sign they’re attached.If the client doesnapost switch between cuddlers, it can lead to an attachment in the long run which I want to avoid.Itaposs important that people come to the session with the right intention and in the consultation, I make sure that cuddle therapy is right for them. Now, Kristiina has been a cuddle therapist for three years and has found love with her new partner Matt, .Matt is thrilled that Kristiina has a career that makes her happy however she says that not many people have the same open-mindedness as her partner.She said: “Initially, my mum was terried - she was so concerned for my safety.“She then saw how happy it was making me and that I was doing really well in a safe space.These days, thereaposs a big community in London and itaposs becoming more normalised so people are becoming more curious about the benefits of healing touch.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Mental healthTherapy" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Exclusive: Ive had no heating for month as cant afford bills and food - I share bed with kids to stay warmMum-of-two Beth Connock, who is a full-time carer for her disabled son, has to share a bed with her children to keep them warm after a hike in the price of oil left them without heatingThe family have been left without heating for a month Image: Beth ConnockByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Feb |commentsSingle mum Beth Connock can no longer afford to keep the house warm AND feed her two children after her heating bills soared by  per cent. The -year-old mum of two - who is a full-time carer to disabled son Tommy, aged  - has now lived without heating for more than a month.“Itaposs really upsetting because I feel like a failure of a mother. I can choose between keeping my house warm at the moment and feeding the kids. “And the kids need to be fed but they need to be warm, it’s quite upsetting. No one should have to choose between feeding or eating.” Beth is one of the . million UK householders whose heating is powered by oil as her home in the rural hamlet of Dartshill, Somerset does not have a mains gas supply.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here Her problem started as the cost to heat her family home, which she rents, rose sharply - from £ to £ for  litres, to fill less than half the tank.The cost of living crisis has left the mum, Tommy, five, and Gabby, three, forced to share a bed each night.They have a tiny electric heater to warm the bedroom they share, but in the evenings, they can see their breath in their living room when the temperature drops. Desperate to keep her children warm, Beth bundles them up in jumpers and scarves at home - but Tommy, who is autistic, struggles to wear the outfits. She says: “We’re wearing a lot of extra layers and having to sleep in the same bed to keep warm. “I shut the bedroom door to keep our body heat in but as soon as we got downstairs, it is freezing and we’re all shivering. “It’s a very old draughty cottage, I woke up the other morning around  am to find ice around the windowsill. “We’re wearing a lot more clothes, which means a lot more washing and a backlog of clothes as we wait days for things to dry. “It’s also a choice when it comes to hot water -the kids have a bath, I can’t have a shower as well.” She added: “I have no money and I’m worried about the kids getting ill because it is so cold. “February and March can be the coldest months so I needed to get something done quickly.” Tommy, aged five, is “very delayed” and has to wear specic clothes, meaning he doesn’t like wearing the extra layers.Beth is unable to work after becoming his full-time carer due to his severe epilepsy and the family rely on Universal Credit to get by.She previously tried to get a loan but was refused as she still owes around £ from the last loan she received. “I’ve tried everything. I even tried to get a grant in my local area but I heard nothing back,” the mum said. She also claims disability allowance to support him, who spent nine weeks in hospital in , suffering constant seizures. He has to wear a helmet to protect himselfhe falls, and mum Beth is on constant alert for his seizures. “Because of his epilepsy and autism, he is very delayed, and he doesn’t understand why we need to wear these extra clothes,” added Beth. “So trying to keep him warm it’s really dficult, he’s used to having heating and now we don’t have it. “It’s very frustrating for him.”  The desperate mum recently turned toGoFundMeto help cover the £ bill - where one kindhearted stranger donated £ anonymously.The hike in the price of oil comes amid a cost of living crisis with Beth’s rent recently rising by £ per month - a rise she will struggle to cover. Struggling Brits are bracing for further financial turmoil this spring - with tax rises, wage cuts and soaring bills set to batter household budgets further.The cost of living crisis could see families suffer a £, a year average hit, The Mirror exclusively revealed today - in a further blow to families such as Bethaposs.Low-income families are set to be the most affected by the crisis - with no spending they can cut back on. She said: “We scrape by every month, it’s dficult. With Universal Credit, I don’t knowthey’ll cover the rent increase. “As a single mum on benefits, £ is a lot of money. “Tommy’s school is about half an hour away so I do an hour-round journey every day to get him there. “It got to the point where I was desperate for heating and I just had to set up a GoFundMe page.” She plans to donate any excess to the Daisy Garland charity, that supported her family while Tommy was in the hospital.Donate to Beth’sGoFundMehere.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HospitalsOil pricesSingle mumEpilepsyAsperger’s syndromeEnergy bills" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Lovable window cleaner, , found dead after failing to show up for workJonathan Titcombe, , was a "lovable" and "very popular" window cleaner in Caldicot, Monmouthshire, who was found dead at his home after failing to turn up for workJonathan Titcombe, , was found dead at his home Image: walesonlineByJonathon HillTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsThe heartbroken family of a window cleaner who was found dead at his home have told of how he was very popular and well known in the community. Jonathan Titcombe, , was a lovable and recognisable face in Caldicot, Monmouthshire, having spent most of his working le at window cleaners Tim Parsons and Sons.He was found dead at his home on January  after he failed to turn up for work, reported WalesOnline. Affectionately known in the town as JT, Jonathan suffered from epilepsy but the cause of his death is currently unknown.He is survived by his five siblings, mother Tracy, and father Tim.  His family said they grew concerned for him when he failed to show up for work on the morning of January  with his sister Danielle said was very unusual. Tracy said: “He was a lovable person, yes. A very lovable guy and he was a kind and caring man. He was very popular and well-known in the community. “He’d been a window cleaner for many years with his dad and was always recognised in the town..” Jonathan’s sister Danielle said: “We are absolutely heartbroken. With the honour of my brother the business will continue.  He was adored by his aunties and cousins too as well as by us. Words cannot describe what a massive hole this has left in our family. Le will never be the same without him.” Jonathanaposs brother Josh added: We might not have always seen eye to eye but we always had each othersapos backs. Thataposs just family and the power of caring for someone no matter what. In our younger days we were the all time partners of all mischief. Car badges, dust caps, hot wheels and the sweet aisles in any shop never stood a chance. Danielle said her family had been “touched by everyone” after hundreds of tributes were paid to Jonathan on social media. One comment read: “Absolutely gutted to hear this awful news. title: man given days live after
story: Man given days to live after blood cancer symptoms dismissed as old age for  yearsRetired bus driver Brian Mellor, , from Blackpool, was found unable to move last year after bending down to wash his hands - he has since been diagnosed with cancerBrians cancer went undiagnosed for  years as doctors put symptoms down to old ageByRebecca LockwoodLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A retired bus driver nearly died after his incurable blood cancer went undiagnosed for  years after his symptoms were put down to old age.Brian Mellor, , from Blackpool, couldnapost move after his femur and hip had split open for no logical reason.Brianaposs daughter, Alyson Yates, , and husband Alan are planning weekly gigs throughout March to raise money for Myeloma UK which funds research into a cure which almost claimed her fatheraposs le last year, reports Lancashire Live.Doctors had reportedly dismissed Brianaposs previous symptoms, aches and pains as old age. Tests continued tonegative and the family felt nobody could explain what was wrong with him. Brian was found aposunable to moveapos on May  last year after bending down to wash his hands. Little did we know that our world was about to be blown apart, Alyson said. My dad suddenly was unable to move and we had to call an ambulance. It came to light that my dadaposs femur and hip had split open but there was no logical reason for this he hadnapost banged himself or had a fall. On the May  after much investigation it came to light that my dad had myeloma and was very poorly. He wasnapost even awake so I couldn’t tell him how much I loved him and that he had to fight. The next day, Alyson said she had to discuss a do-not-resuscitate order with her fatheraposs consultant. What a shocker, she said, we only found out about the cancer the day before and he only came into hospital  days before that. How can things be this bad so quick  May  was one of the worst days of our le, Alyson continued. We got a call to say come in, Dad wasnapost going to be pulling through, and would not make the weekend. To this point we had all been restricted to seeing my dad because of Covid but now we were allowed to be by his side. I cannot emphasise what a shock this week had been to us all. How quick the tide had turned in our le. What I can tell you is from my own point of view the heart-breaking pain I felt, Iaposd never felt pain like it and it was like I could not breathe and my world had crashed into a million pieces.  Sadly, a lot of families go through this journey leading to their diagnosis. Another reason why knowledge, awareness, training and earlier diagnosis is so important. Myeloma is an incurable blood cancer that occurs in the bone marrow. It currently affects more than , people in the UK. On average,  people are diagnosed with Myeloma every day in the UK. Alyson said: My dad had fallen sick in October  and despite many tests ran nothing came to light. Even a few weeks before May st, Dad had more tests done and still nothing had shown up, even in the blood tests for cancer. Going back through my dadaposs medical history it is now thought that his myeloma could go back  years when it was at the apossmoulderingapos stage but right up to him being hospitalised nothing ever came to light. The myeloma had remained undetected. Another reason why a better diagnosis system needs to be found. Despite being told he had just days to live, Brian went home in July - a day that Alyson says is one they never thought we would see. Brian is said to have responded well to chemotherapy - but the damage done to his body cannot be reversed. He is on chemotherapy every day to give him some extra time. Another dficult side to Myeloma is that it does y from person to person and besides the cancer, myeloma can come with many other complications. For my dad it is his heart and lungs. Now Alyson and husband Alan, who run Alan Yates Music, are planning to do weekly gigs throughout March this year in a bid to fund the research into a cure for Myeloma.Alyson is immunocompromised, meaning her immune system is extremely weak and she is at higher risk of contracting Covid-.Myeloma may become curable but funds are required for that and funds are required to help those in today’s society where there isnapost a cure, she said. She said she wanted to support Myeloma UK to help fund research into a cure and to raise awareness of Myeloma so “it doesn’t happen to anybody . We went through a horrendous journey as a family and the thought of another family going through that… I just can’t”. Myeloma UK is the only organisation in the UK exclusively dedicated to Myeloma and its related conditions. They rely almost entirely on voluntary donations and fundraising. Their ultimate goal is to find a cure for Myeloma and until then aim to help every patient live well with the diagnosis for as long as possible.To find out more about myeloma and the work of Myeloma UK click here. story: Miracle puppy SURVIVES after being hurled from flat-bed truck at mphHorried bystanders thought it was a teddy bear that was thrown from the drivers side window at about .pm on Friday in Yalding, KentFreya was thrown out of a flat-bed truck travelling mph in Yalding, Kent on FridayByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Feb |comments A puppy that was thrown out of a flat-bed truck at mph miraculously survived.Horried bystanders thought it was a teddy bear that had been tossed from the driveraposs side window at about .pm on Friday in Yalding, Kent. When they rushed to help they were shocked to discover it was a one-year-old terrier cross, who was malnourished and dirty. The pup, who has now been named Freya, was wrapped in a towel by Deborah Hollingdale, who watched the scene unfold. She said: The woman in the car behind saw an arm stick out of the driveraposs window and threw something out as they were going about pmh. She thought it was a teddy bear at first, then she saw it was a dog which ran onto my drive. I found her, she wasnapost making any noise. The first thing I noticed was that she looked starved. She was just skin and bones, you could see her hip bones poking through. Her fur was matted, she was covered in her own mess and she smelt terrible. It was clear she had been living in her own filth.  Deborah rushed the injured dog to a local vet for immediate emergency treatment and has since visited to check on her recovery. She added: Sheaposs still very thin, sheaposs getting lots of small meals to help build her up gradually. She gave me a little lick when she saw me, it broke my heart. Iaposm so thankful she survived being thrown out of that van. Given the state she was in I donapost think sheaposd have survived much longer living in the conditions she was being kept. Vets alerted the RSPCA, who are now investigating, after finding Freya was underweight, suffering from fleas and had a matted, dirty coat. Inspector Kirsten Ormerod, of the animal welfare charity, said: Freya was incredibly lucky to survive after being hurled from the moving vehicle at such a high speed and vets were incredibly concerned that she may have suffered internal bleeding so performed surgery immediately. for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email.Vets are monitoring her closely and have given her pain relief and I am keeping everything crossed that she pulls through after experiencing such callous cruelty. Witnesses described her being thrown with such force that she landed on the opposite side of the road, and the vehicle didnapost stop or even slow down. Weaposre following up some lines of enquiry in the local area but Iaposm really keen to hear from any other witnesses who saw what happened or has any additional information about the vehicle, the people who were travelling in the truck, or Freya herself. The RSPCA has released adorable pictures of Freya, who is not microchipped and had no identication tag, with a sparkly bandage around her left paw in a bid to find who harmed her. Anyone who recognises the black and tan curly-haired pooch, saw the truck, or has CCTV or dash-cam footage from the area, is urged to contact the RSPCA. story: Mum livid as frightened girl, , abandoned in dark by bus driver due to faulty machineDaiva Paskeviciene, from Edinburgh, said that her daughter was twice denied on board buses due to a problem with her pass and is now scared to use public transportA mum was left fuming after her daughter was twice denied on buses Image: edinburghliveByIona YoungTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsA furious mum has told how her frightened -year-old daughter was left in the dark and cold after a bus driver wouldnapost allow her on board due to a faulty ticket machine. Daiva Paskeviciene, from Edinburgh,said that her daughter, a pupil at Tollcross Primary School, was not allowed on the bus because her pass did not work, and claimed it was a fault with the machine.The first alleged incident happened on January  when the schools had just gone back after Christmas break, reported EdinburghLive.Ms Paskeviciene said she received a call from her terried daughter after she was left alone waiting in the cold for  minutes for another bus home. The -year-old is claimed to have presented her junior ridacard, that had been topped up that morning, to the machine on the bus. The driver told her it wasnapost working so she could not get on and would have to leave the bus. Ms Paskeviciene told EdinburghLive: My daughter is in P at Tollcross and is -years-old, it happened after Christmas when schools went back. Usually she gets the bus, on that day at around .pm. She went to the bus with her bus card that I topped up that morning. The machine wasnapost working so the driver told her she couldnapost get on the bus. He then got angry and was shouting at her. She got really scared. The bus stop was at Lothian Road, she had to wait  minutes for the next one it got dark and very cold. She called me and eventually a stranger had to give her money to be able to get home. Next time I made sure she had spare change just in case.  I couldnapost believe a driver would act like that to a little girl then it happened again. She got a new bus card the free Young Scot one, it worked in the morning on the bus but again when she was trying to get on the  after school, she tapped her card and it didnapost work. The driver said, aposyour card doesnapost work, you arenapost coming onapos my daughter called me crying, and is now afraid to catch the bus to school. A spokesman for Lothian Buses said: Lothian is committed to delivering safe, reliable public transport for all of our customers. We would always ask that our customers contact our customer services teamthey have concerns regarding their travel experience and would encourage this customer to contact us directly with more information to allow us to investigate the matter. title: nestle shutting down uk factory
story: Nestle shutting down UK factory with Brit favourites set to be made in Eastern EuropeProduction of popular items such as Fruit Pastilles, Toffee Crisps and mini eggs will be moved to Nestle plants in the Czech Republic, Poland and Bulgaria - after the factory in Newcastle is set to shut in Nestlés factory at Fawdon, Newcastle Upon Tyne, will shut in  Image: Rod Kirkpatrick F Stop PressByGraeme WhitfieldAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsNestle is shutting down a factory in the UK to start producing confectionary abroad.The former Rowntree factory in Newcastle will shut and switch to some production in eastern Europe in .At least  jobs will be lost and consultations with staff have moved to closure plans after Nestle rejected pleas from unions to reconsider, ChronicleLive reports. Production of popular items such as Fruit Pastilles, Toffee Crisps and mini eggs will be moved to Nestle plants in the Czech Republic, Poland and Bulgaria. While other items will be produced in Halax.  The factory, which first opened in , makes all the Rolos in the world and also produces a range of sweets that includes Caramac and Munchies. GMB national officer Ross Murdoch said: “Closing this profit-making site and shting production to Europe is completely unacceptable. This will have a devasting impact on workers and their families. “Meanwhile transporting finished products from sites in Europe back to the UK - where they are consumed - will result in signicant additional road and sea miles increasing pollution and environmental damage.  “GMB and Unite will now speak to members in Fawdon and find out what they want to do next. We will give them whatever support and resources they need to fight this.” Joe Clarke, a national officer at Unite the Union, said: “Unite and its membership are bitterly disappointed that alternative proposals to keep the site within Nestle Fawdon open have been rejected.  “We are currently seeking further information in relation to the proposal, and we will enter into dialogue on next steps imminently.” A Nestle spokesman said: “The consultation around the changes we proposed in April  is still ongoing. “We said from the outset that we wanted to provide adequate time and space for these discussions and it is only right that they are held directly with our employees and trade unions and not in public. It remains a priority to support our people and their families through this process and we thank everybody for their patience. “We will provide an update once the consultation is complete.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON UniteRowntree PLCNestle UK Ltd." data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: push identify brit dubbed gentleman
story: Push to identy Brit dubbed the Gentleman found off coast of Germany  years agoThe mystery man, thought to be British and aged between  and , was wearing distinctive size  handmade luxury English shoes and a woollen tie. He was washed up off HeligolandAn artist reconstruction of the mystery man Image: HandoutByTom PettorCrime Editor:,  Feb |commentsBritish experts have appealed for help identying a ft in suspected murder victim dubbed The Gentleman who was found off the German coast  years ago. The mystery man, thought to be British and aged between  and , was wearing distinctive size  handmade luxury English shoes and a woollen tie. He was washed up off Heligoland, a small archipelago on the north-west coast of Germany, on July , . The man had died up to seven months earlier, had injuries to his head and upper body and had been weighed down by his suspected killer or killers. Forensic psychologists from Goldsmiths, University of London, the University of Staffordshire and Plymouth Marjon University have been drafted in to try and identy him. Fiona Gabbert, Professor of Psychology and Director of the Forensic Psychology Unit at Goldsmiths, said: “We believe that the man is likely to have gone missing somewhere between the end of  and the first six months of  so we’re calling on the public to think back to that time. “Our research shows that activating memories from a particular period can help iniduals remember more information from that particular time so we’re asking you to read through a list of news and events that happened in  . “Take a while to think where you were and who you knew at this time. Do you think you might know the man we are seeking to identy ” Top stories at the time included the death of Pablo Escobar , the IRA Heathrow bombings, the death of Nirvana singer Kurt Cobain, O.J. Simpson’s arrest and the inauguration of Nelson Mandela as President of South Africa. The man was slim, weighing around  to  stone. His hair colour andand eye colour are all unknown. He was from an English-speaking area so may have been British or had links to Britain.His black or navy leather loafers were made by upmarket shoemakers Church Co Limited.They had been re-soled with Philipps soles and had replacement heels manufactured by Dinky Heel PLC, Bristol, with the inscription I.T.S. Jubilee and a stylised crown. He was wearing a % wool tie which was dark blue with grey, brown, orange and green diagonal stripes. The tie’s label included instructions in English and French to dry clean only. His navy trousers were made in France and he was wearing a long-sleeved, light blue shirt with collar. His body may have been thrown off a ship off Heligoland or entered from Heligoland and moved out to sea. The German authorities are being supported in the UK by charity Locate International. title: retired british airways jet bought
story: Retired British Airways jet bought for £ transformed into £,-an-hour party planeThe British Airways Negus jet has been remodelled into an events space to host everything from private birthday parties to product launches and corporate eventsThe BA Negus jet has been remodelled into an events space Image: @negus   SWNSByTom Bevan:,  Feb  A classic  British Airways jet has undergone a dramatic transformation into a “party plane” which will be available for revellers to hire.The BA Negus jet has been remodelled into an events space to host everything from private birthday parties to product launches and corporate events, and is now sitting pretty at the privately-owned Cotswolds Airport near Wiltshire. It was bought for just £ in  by the airportaposs chief executive Suzannah Harvey when British Airways retired its fleet early due to the pandemic, and has been a labor of love ever since. Suzannah said: I paid a pound for her, and we have a certain obligation to maintain it as is practical for public use. The company has had to spend nearly £, getting her prepped and ready here, but I think itaposs money well spent and it preserves her for future generations.  Most of the original structure has stayed the same but the transformation has included stripping out the economy section to create the events space and turning the gallery into a bar. A full rewiring with custom lighting has been done while it also took one man a whole week and a half to give it a good clean inside and out. Suzannah described the renovation process as a “long old slog”.  “She came into us in October , and at the time I rather naively thought weaposd have her up and running by the following Easter,” she said. Weaposve had such tremendous support from everybody. All the contractors, all the people that have volunteered who are current BA  engineers - and here we are finally. “Sheaposs ready and sheaposs good to go. The Negus entered the British Airways fleet on  February , operating , flights - flying for , hours over nearly  million miles.  Its last passenger flight was from Miami to Heathrow on  April, .Anyone now wanting to host a party onboard will have to pay more than £, an hour but Suzannah said they had been inundated with enquiries - including from Netflix.Suzannah added: The vision has finally come to fruition, with overwhelming support from volunteers including current BA engineers and half a million pounds of investment later, Negus  is finally ready.  Preserved for many years to come and future generations, Negus is the only bespoke events  in the world. Cotswold Airport is family owned and operated and is the largest privately owned airport in Europe having a runway only m shorter than Bristol International. Suzannah said an app will soon be launched to enable the general public to book tours of the aircraft. title: school makes parents sign contract
story: School makes parents sign contract to say homosexuality is a sin - or will expel kidsThe contract is lumping students who are unsure about their sexuality or unsure about their gender identity... with the likes paedophiles and adulterersFormer Citipointe Christian College student Felicity Myers Image: AAP PA ImagesByKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA school has sparked outrage after asking parents to sign a contract saying that homosexuality is a sin or their child will be expelled. Despite the backlash, headteacher Brian Mulheran, of the Citipointe Christian College, has doubled down and given parents an extra two weeks to sign their children up. The contract was sent to families last Friday and said the college will only enrol the student on the basis of the gender that corresponds to their biological sex. It also asserted that homosexuality, along with bestiality, incest and paedophilia, was sinful. One teacher, who also has a student at the college, has already resigned saying young people within the LGBTQ+ community deserve to feel safe while at school. Helen Clapham Burns was also a teacher at the school in Carindale, Australia, but quit on Monday saying she couldnapost continue to work for a school that would do that to children.  Mrs Burns said: Iaposm heartbroken. I feel like Iaposve let them down that Iaposm having to leave. But I have to let those queer kids know that there are Christians out there that love them and arenapost hiding behind Bible verses and are letting them know that they are safe with me. As an educator, my priority is to make sure that each child that I interact with feels safe. When a child tells us, with tears in their eyes, that they donapost feel safe, what are we doing  Mr Mulheran made a video for parents about the contract. In it he said he had listened to their concerns and wanted them to make the right decisions for themselves. The declaration of faith has been in place for the whole of last year, he said.  We want families to consider this ethos so that they can make the right decisions for themselves. He added: We have always held these Christian beliefs and we have tried to be fair and transparent to everyone in our community by making them clear in the enrolment contract. We are seeking to maintain our Christian ethos and to give parents and students the right to make an informed choice about whether they can support and embrace our approach to Christian education. Citipointe does not judge students on their sexuality or gender identity and we would not make a decision about their enrolment in the College simply on that basis.  A group of parents has said they want to file a complaint to the Human Rights Commission, arguing they were not consulted about the contract and that the college was discriminating against students on the basis of sexuality and gender identity. One parent who is asked not to be named said: The contract they put out is so blatantly damaging to anyone within the school who identies within the LGBTQI umbrella are not of their highest concern. But nor is anybody  who believes in standing up against this kind of discrimination, because the contract makes it clear that any kind of act that goes against this belief is something that can be disciplined. Federal Member for Moncref, Angie Bell, told ABC Radio in Brisbane she disagreed with the college lumping students who are unsure about their sexuality or unsure about their gender identity ... with the likes paedophiles and adulterers. No school child should be discriminated against based on their sexual orientation, their gender identity, their pregnancy status, or their relationship status, which are the four elements that are in that section of the Sex Discrimination Act, she said.Religious organisations also have the right to practise their faith … without a doubt … notitaposs done in a discriminatory fashion. This is not  anymore … this is a new year, this is a new decade, this is a new Australia and there is no room. story: Two-legged dog who has never been loved is searching for a place to call homeLalia has been living on the streets of Cario unable to use her back leg - but Miracles Mission has stepped up to transform her le" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _streetdogJPG.jpg" width"" "" Lalia, a mixed-breed dog, has been living on the streets of Cario unable to use her back legs. ByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA two-legged dog who doesn’t know what it is like to be loved is desperately searching for a home. Lalia, a mixed-breed dog, has been living on the streets of Cario unable to use her back legs. One of her legs was so badly damaged that it had to be amputated, while the other still hangs lelessly on her body. It is unknown how long Lalia has been living like this - but Miracleaposs Mission has stepped up to transform her le. The animal welfare organisation, who work with sick, injured and disabled animals worldwide, wants to rehome Lalia in the UK - and already have a flight booked for her. However, as she has received no online interest from any potential owners, her spot on the plane might remain empty at take off.A statement on Twitter reads: “Laila will miss her flightwe donapost find a suitable foster this week.“She cannot thrive in a shelter environment - she really needs a home.” Lalia is currently being fostered in Egypt - but is ready to travel as soon as a new owner comes forward. A statement reads: “Laila is a sweet girl who gets around and will likely benefit from a set of wheels to aid her mobility on walks. “Laila is good with other dogs. She would rather not live with children or cats. “Shelter le is particularly dficult for dogs like Laila with disabilities, so we really would like for her to travel as soon as possible.  “She is incontinent and will require bladder expression three or four times a day. This is easy to do and we offer full training in this to all prospective foster and forever families.” Miracle’s Mission is a UK registered animal welfare charity who work predominantly in the UK, Borneo and Egypt. Founded by Victoria Bryceson in , they aim to provide safety and support to animals in need worldwide. A statement reads: “Our mission is to provide a place of safety for animals in danger, to educate on the needs of neutering both pets and strays and to neuter stray dogs and cats to prevent the birth of more animals onto the streets. story: UK weather forecast: Exact day cm of snow to fall as Arctic blast brings -C freezeThe UK is set to face an Arctic blast on Friday with temperatures tumbling to -C and then there will be several days of snow leading to over cm predicted to fall on SundayAn Arctic blast is set to hit the country on Friday Image: NurPhoto PA ImagesByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsBrits are being warned of severe gales before an Arctic blast hits at the end of week bringing several days of snow with nire than cm predicted to fall on Sunday.After a milder few days a cold weather front is expected to sweep in on Friday bringing freezing temperatures as low as - in Scotland and a light covering of snow.Met Office forecaster Clare Nasir said: “A transition from mild to cold over the next  hours after an active cold front delivers heavy rain and gales as it moves from the North West down towards the South East.”Before that on Thursday, there is expected to be plenty of cloud especially on the western side of the UK before strong gale conditions arrive in the afternoon. “This is the front coming in across the western side of Scotland and the winds will pick up to gales, perhaps even severe gales in the latter part of the day with some strong gusts,” said Ms Nasir.  The cold weather s on Friday with some snow which will get a lot heavier by Sunday. Ms Nasir continued: “The air remains mild through Thursday evening and thenyou are waking up in the South East on Friday morning some heavy rain before it turns clearer and colder from the north. Wintry showers to follow in the more northern and western areas. The snow is expected for higher ground on Friday in most parts of the country.  “Here is that rain and behind that the air is a lot colder so as the rain passes down through Scotland, Northern Ireland, northern England, said Ms Nasir. You can see a little bit of snow on its back edge, so cm to cm above m just for a time as it sweeps down towards the South East during the early hours of Friday morning with wintry showers to follow and again the risk of snow about m to m.” People will need to wrap up warm on Friday, especially in the north of the country. title: with cristiano ronaldo side pestered
story: With Cristiano Ronaldo on their side, pestered parents can win phone battleEva Simpson cheers on the Manchester United footballer who is refusing to spoil his young son with tech and gadgets. Cristiano Ronaldo said his -year-old son isn’t allowed a phoneCristiano Ronaldo is refusing to cave in Image: Visionhaus Getty ImagesopinionByEva Simpson:,  Feb |comments I don’t have much in ­common with Cristiano Ronaldo.He’s a multimillionaire ­footballer with luxurious homes across the world and an army of fans and followers on social media. I’m a mum working from a wobbly table in the kitchen. So I was surprised to find out there is one thing we agree on: our attitude towards ­children and gadgets.Earlier this week the Manchester United star revealed his -year-old son Cristiano Jnr – who presumably could have anything money can buy – isn’t allowed a phone, despite constantly pestering him for one.Ronaldo warned of the dangers of being “obsessed” with technology and shared a story that most parents with young children will know only too well – little ones demanding phones. Speaking about tech, Ronaldo said: “Definitely it helps a lot. It helped me and the people here, all the world, and I think we have to take advantage of that but we shouldn’t be obsessed with it.”  He went on: “My oldest child is going to be  years old soon and he asks me every time, ‘Daddy, can I have a phone, can I have a phone, can I have a phone ’ I say to him, ‘Cristiano, you have time.’” I can’t believe he’s been able to hold out for so long. My six-year-old asks, on an almost daily basis,he can have a phone, insisting all his friends have one. The answer is obviously no – he’s far too young and I know most of his friends don’t own one – but nonetheless it is a source of contention. The few times I’ve given him my smartphone to play games or watch a show on, there’s a full-blown meltdown when it comes to getting it back.  When I think about ­children and gadgets, I often recall the words of Steve Jobs, when he was askedhis kids loved one of his greatest inventions: the iPad.He said: “They haven’t used it. We limit the amount of technology our children use at home.” See, even the great Jobs didn’t let his kids loose on gadgets. Technology is important but it’s far better for kids to be creative, make up their own games and, where possible, play outside. That’s what childhood should be about, not being glued to a screen. So now when my son whines, I have the perfect reply. If it’s good enough for Ronaldo’s son not to have a phone, then it’s good enough for you. title: woman 65 diagnosed early onset
story: Exclusive: Woman, , diagnosed with early-onset dementia determined to live le to the fullWendy Mitchell lives with a combination of early onset Alzheimer’s and vascular dementia, diagnosed in  when she was just . She has made a vocation of educating on dementiaWendy Mitchell has early onset dementia Image: Hull News  PictureByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer:,  Feb |commentsThe ducks know Wendy Mitchell, greeting their old friend in a gentle huddle before she even opens her carrier bag of seed. “Because I come every day they remember me,” she says, beaming at the cacophony of quacking, feeding a couple of the birds from her cupped palm. But while the ducks in the village pond know her, Wendy does not know them at least, she can’t remember them, or doing this.She lives with a combination of Alzheimer’s and vascular dementia, diagnosed in  when she was just .We are at the start of a walk around her village, aptly named Walkington, in East Yorkshire, which she usually repeats two or three times a day. Yet, like the duck feeding, in this moment it is as new for her as it is for me.  These “trundles” give her autonomy, essential to the strict routine she has adopted that helps her continue to live independently . In place of her “memory”, she always slings a camera around her neck, snapping landmarks, birds, animals, treesso when she gets home she can reflect on what she’s done. It sounds like a perpetual Groundhog Day – only for Wendy, it isn’t. Her pedometer has been known to read , steps, but while each might feel familiar, it’s always a first. “Yes, every time, the walk is new,” she nods, brightly. “I don’t remember feeding the ducks yesterday. I know I did, whether it was rainy or sunny I don’t know, orthey came to me straight away like this.  “Once I start up it feels familiar, but every day I’m feeding them for the first time. I never get bored.” When wein an hour, she will admit only knowing she has fed the ducks because her bag is empty. But her fresh eyes, the ability to enjoy things anew, are dementia’s “blessings”, she insists. “I live in the moment. The moment is the only thing we all have for certain. You can learn a lot from people with dementia,” she says.Wendy, , once a super-organised NHS manager with “a photographic memory”, has made a vocation of educating on the disease.Her first book, Somebody I Used to Know, was a bestseller, and her second, What I Wish People Knew About Dementia, written with ghostwriter Anna Wharton, is out now.  As we walkWendy admits she hasn’t always been able to see the positives. Her diagnosis in  was harrowing, and she became depressed. The single mum and her two grown-up daughters knew nothing about dementia. “The process is so negative, it focuses on what you have lost. They say there is nothing you can do and you’re discharged. I was just waiting to die.” Testament to her strength she pulled herself up, mainly for her daughters. Of course she has bad, “foggy” days when she cannot go out, clinging to the sight of her window boxes from bed. This morning wasn’t good. “Every morning I play Scrabble and Solitaire, andI can only make two-letter words, like today, I know it’s a bad morning,” she says.  But so articulate is Wendy, so fiercely independent – she insists her daughters don’t visit every day – it is only the sporadic pauses to find a word that alert me to her dementia. But it affects her in so many ways. Dementia is not just about memory. A surprising fact: she no longer gets hungry or thirsty. She eats and drinks only as a , setting reminders. Her taste has changed too. Her beloved cup of Yorkshire Tea is flavourless to her now. She needs familiarity, so eats the same meal every day for weeks. Currently it’s fish pie.But Wendy struggles to use a kneand fork, and even to see pale food on a white plate.Dementia has played with her eyesight. Anything black, for example, can look like a void.She has hallucinations. “Joyfully” she has seen her late father. And olfactory hallucinations, too. Once a smell of smoke in the house convinced her there was a fire.Her hearing is also affected and loud noises can “physically hurt”.  But as we walk towards the church, she stops when she hears a robin. She can name the birdsong instantly this is an “old memory”. The past is still clear to her, it comes to her in dreams. We pause for  minutes for a picture. Later I remark on how many robin photos she will have. “Have I ” she replies, eagerly. We loop round, today avoiding a field route. Paths she knows will lead back home, in the fields she has become lost. It’s the outline of a row of cottages she clings to, the sound of shrieks in the school playground. Everyone says hello. Wendy replies happily, but explains: “I haven’t a clue who people are.” Worn out, she will need to head home after this to sit in silence, eyes closed. It’s a strange feeling to know she won’t recall me or our walk. “But I will remember the emotion of you,” she assures me. “I will know I met someone with a smiley face.” She now has, she says, only three emotions: happiness, contentment and sadness. She insists she is lucky as others can be left with anger, jealousy. And what about fear  Wendy doesn’t have any of it – “another blessing”, she explains. She once “didn’t like rollercoasters”, but since her dementia, she has been skying. “I’ve now seen an advert for wingwalking,” she adds with a twinkle. She continues: “I can’t say enough how lucky I am. You must never give up on yourself. Don’t underestimate what you can achieve, even at your lowest.” At her front door her sharp eyes spot one final thing. My bag in her porch. It is me that has forgotten it, me who doesn’t have the sharply trained eyes to spot it. Wendy laughs heartily.
